tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires understanding bending moment diagrams and applying them to a specific beam configuration. It involves analyzing the image and understanding structural mechanics principles to determine the correct bending moment distribution, which requires multiple steps of reasoning.

answer_validation.reasoning: The beam has two simple supports separated by 2L and an overhang of length L to the right, with a pure end moment M applied at the free end. A pure moment does not create any net vertical force, so the support reactions are equal and opposite vertical forces whose line of action passes through the span between supports. For a statically determinate beam with only a couple applied, the internal bending moment between the supports is constant (no distributed load or shear), so the BMD over the 2L span is a straight line with constant magnitude. Over the overhang, there is no shear or additional load, so the bending moment varies linearly from its value at the right support to the applied end moment at the free end. At the left support, the bending moment must be zero because a simple support cannot resist a moment. Therefore, the BMD starts from zero at the left support, increases linearly to a constant nonzero value at the right support, and then decreases linearly back to zero at the free end where the applied couple is located (sign change at the end). Among the options, diagram (B) matches this: triangular distribution starting from zero at the left support, peaking at the right support, and returning to zero at the free end of the overhang.

step_by_step: Identify loading and supports: A simply supported span of length 2L with an overhang of length L to the right, and a pure end moment M applied at the free end of the overhang.

Note that a pure moment (couple) produces no net vertical force. Therefore, the sum of vertical reactions at the two supports must be zero; one reaction is upward and the other downward with equal magnitude. There is no distributed load or point load along the beam.

Between the two supports, the shear force is constant (equal to the reaction at the left support), but since there is no distributed load, the derivative of bending moment with respect to x is constant. However, because the net vertical load between supports is zero (one reaction up, one down), the internal bending moment between supports is actually constant in magnitude and sign.

At a simple support, the bending moment is zero because the support cannot resist a couple. Thus, the BMD must be zero at the left support and at the right support if considered independently; but the presence of the applied end moment shifts the internal moment distribution so that only the left support has zero moment, while the right support carries a nonzero internal moment to balance the end couple.

Over the main span from left to right support, with no distributed load, the bending moment varies linearly between its value at the left support (zero) and its value at the right support (maximum). This gives a straight-line increase, forming the rising side of a triangle.

Over the overhang from the right support to the free end, again there is no distributed load, so bending moment varies linearly. It must reduce from its peak value at the right support to zero at the free end where the applied couple is located (the external couple cancels the internal moment). This forms the descending side of the triangle.
Thus the overall BMD is triangular: zero at the left support, maximum at the right support, and zero again at the free end of the overhang. This matches option B.

topic.name: Shear force and bending moment diagrams
topic.syllabus_ref: Structures -> Bending of beams, shear force and bending moment diagrams

concepts.name: Bending moment diagram for beams with couples and overhangs
Relationship between load, shear force, and bending moment
Qualitative shape of BMD without detailed calculation

essential: Basic statics: equilibrium of forces and moments in beams
Concept of bending moment and shear force in beams
Effect of a pure moment (couple) versus a transverse load
Support types: simple support versus fixed support
Qualitative drawing of shear force and bending moment diagrams
helpful: Differential relationships between load, shear, and bending moment
Experience with beams having overhangs and end loads

Main Concept: requires: Basic statics and free-body diagrams
requires: Understanding of internal forces and moments in beams
enables: Quick qualitative prediction of SFD and BMD for complex beams
enables: Preliminary structural design and checking for maximum bending stresses

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that a pure moment does not create net vertical reaction but does create internal bending moment
Students may be confused by the overhang and think the BMD must be more complex than a simple triangle

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Beams with concentrated moments and overhangs
textbook_references.text_snippet: Examples of simply supported and overhanging beams subjected to end couples illustrate the resulting linear variation of bending moment and the triangular shape of the BMD.

textbook_references.author: Beer and Johnston
textbook_references.text_snippet: Analysis of beams with distributed loads, point loads, and couples, including the relationship dM/dx = V and dV/dx = -w.

video_references.book_reference: Megson, Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Shear force and bending moment diagrams for beams with distributed loads and cantilevers

video_references.book_reference: Beer and Johnston, Mechanics of Materials
video_references.topic_covered: Bending moment diagrams for beams with trapezoidal loads and decomposition techniques

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify loading and supports \u2192 Use equilibrium to infer reactions and internal forces \u2192 Apply dM/dx = V with zero distributed load \u2192 Sketch qualitative BMD
key_insights: A pure end moment introduces bending without net shear or vertical reaction along the beam.
With no distributed load, bending moment varies linearly in any region where shear is constant.
Simple supports enforce zero bending moment at their locations unless influenced by external couples transmitted through the structure.

formulas_principles.name: Vertical force equilibrium
formulas_principles.conditions: Static equilibrium of the entire beam
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to deduce that the net vertical reaction due to a pure couple is zero.

formulas_principles.name: Moment equilibrium
formulas_principles.conditions: Static equilibrium including applied end couple
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates internal bending moments and the applied end moment.

formulas_principles.name: Shear-moment relationship
formulas_principles.relevance: Shows that with constant shear and no distributed load, bending moment varies linearly.

formulas_principles.name: Load-shear relationship
formulas_principles.conditions: Distributed load intensity w(x) along the beam
formulas_principles.relevance: Since w = 0 along the beam except at the applied couple, shear is piecewise constant.

industry_examples: Overhanging aircraft wing segments or control surfaces where hinge moments act as couples at the tips.
Crane jibs or cantilevered platforms subjected to applied torques at their free ends.
specific_systems: Aircraft tailplane with elevator hinge moment modeled as an end couple on an overhanging beam.
Ship hull overhangs where mooring loads create end moments.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how pure moments affect bending moment distribution helps engineers place reinforcements and supports efficiently, ensuring that maximum bending stresses remain within allowable limits.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that a pure end moment produces a rectangular (constant) bending moment diagram along the entire beam.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall that a fixed-end beam with a couple has constant moment but forget that here the supports are simple, not fixed.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check support conditions: simple supports cannot resist a moment, so the BMD must be zero at those points.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing option C (rectangular distribution) instead of the correct triangular diagram.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking that the bending moment must be zero at the free end because there is no support there, ignoring the applied couple.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They overgeneralize the rule 'moment is zero at free end of a cantilever' without considering applied end moments.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that internal bending moment at a section equals the algebraic sum of external moments to one side. A couple at the free end can make the internal moment nonzero or zero depending on balance.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect shape of BMD over the overhang, misidentifying where the diagram returns to zero.

common_mistakes.mistake: Believing that no vertical loads means zero bending moment everywhere.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusing shear force with bending moment and not recognizing that a couple alone can create bending.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Differentiate clearly: vertical forces create shear; couples directly create bending moments even without shear.
common_mistakes.consequence: May lead to selecting an option with nearly zero BMD or dismissing the effect of the end moment.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: A pure moment (couple) can bend a beam even without vertical forces.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when deciding whether a region with zero shear can still have nonzero bending moment.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Bending moment at a simple support is zero.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Check BMD endpoints at pins/rollers when sketching diagrams.

flashcards.front: What is the bending moment at a simple (pin or roller) support for a beam?
flashcards.back: The bending moment at a simple support is zero because such supports cannot resist a couple; they only provide vertical (and possibly horizontal) reactions.

flashcards.front: State the differential relationships between load w(x), shear V(x), and bending moment M(x).
flashcards.back: They are: dV/dx = -w(x) and dM/dx = V(x). These hold for Euler-Bernoulli beams under transverse loading.

flashcards.front: For a beam segment with zero distributed load and constant shear, how does bending moment vary along the length?
flashcards.back: With w(x)=0, shear V is constant, so dM/dx = V is constant. Therefore, bending moment varies linearly along that segment.

flashcards.front: A simply supported beam has an overhang with a pure end moment M at the free end. Qualitatively sketch the BMD.
flashcards.back: Start at zero at the left support, increase linearly to a maximum at the right support, then decrease linearly over the overhang to zero at the free end where the applied couple balances the internal moment.

flashcards.front: Why is a rectangular BMD along a simply supported beam with only an end couple incorrect?
flashcards.back: A rectangular (constant) BMD would imply nonzero moment at both supports, but simple supports cannot resist moments. The BMD must be zero at the left support and vary linearly elsewhere.

real_world_context.application: Aircraft wing or tail surfaces experiencing hinge moments from control deflections.
real_world_context.industry_example: When an elevator deflects, it generates a hinge moment at the tailplane tip, modeled as an end couple on an overhanging beam representing the tailplane.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of bending moments can lead to under-designed spars or hinges, risking structural failure during maneuvers.

real_world_context.application: Crane jibs with torque applied at the hook or pulley.
real_world_context.industry_example: A rotating load at the end of a crane boom can be idealized as an end moment, affecting bending in the boom and its supports.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Designers must understand how such moments distribute along the structure to prevent excessive bending and fatigue.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Look at supports and type of loading first. With only a couple and no distributed load, expect linear BMD segments and zero moment at simple supports. Choose the diagram that is triangular with zero at the pin/roller and appropriate behavior at the free end.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: Eliminate any BMD that shows nonzero moment at a simple support or curvature (nonlinear shape) when there is no distributed load.
exam_strategy.time_management: Spend no more than 1â€“2 minutes; this is a quick conceptual question once you recall the load-shear-moment relationships.

search_keywords: bending moment diagram end couple overhanging beam
simply supported beam with overhang and applied moment
shear force and bending moment diagrams pure moment
relationship between load shear and bending moment
GATE AE structures bending of beams examples

alternative_methods.name: Full statics with section cuts
alternative_methods.description: Write equilibrium equations for the entire beam to find reactions, then take a general section at distance x from the left support and write moment equilibrium to derive M(x) piecewise for 0<x<2L and 2L<x<3L. Plot M(x) to obtain the exact BMD.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives exact expressions and reinforces fundamentals. Cons: Slower and unnecessary for a purely qualitative exam question.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when numerical values of moments are required or when practicing derivations for more complex beams.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Wing bending moment distributions under aerodynamic loads are analyzed using similar SFD/BMD concepts.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Actuator hinge moments on control surfaces translate into structural loads modeled as couples.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Deployable booms on satellites experience end torques; their structural response uses the same beam theory.

deeper_dive_topics: Influence lines for bending moment in beams with overhangs
Effect of varying stiffness (EI) on deflection shapes for beams with end moments
Energy methods (Castigliano) to compute deflections due to end couples
Design of beam cross-sections for combined bending and shear in overhanging structures

syllabus_mapping.gate_section: Structures: Bending of beams, shear force and bending moment diagrams
syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Shear force and bending moment diagrams for beams and frames
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely tests qualitative understanding of BMDs for nonstandard loading (pure couple with overhang), which is important for structural reasoning without heavy computation.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks focused on shear force and bending moment diagrams for beams under distributed loads, triangular and trapezoidal loading, and overhang optimization. While not directly about a pure end moment, they reinforced the relationships between load, shear, and bending moment and the qualitative shapes of BMDs. The specific configuration with a pure couple and overhang was answered mainly from internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the maximum bending moment value in terms of M and L for the same beam and require a short derivation.
Modify the problem to include an additional uniformly distributed load over the main span and ask for the combined BMD.
Consider the same geometry but with a point load at the free end instead of a moment and ask for the location of zero bending moment.
Extend to a fixed-pinned beam with an end couple and ask students to compare BMDs for different boundary conditions.

response_json.question_text: Consider a simply supported beam of length 2L with an overhang of length L, loaded by an end moment M, as shown below. The bending moment distribution for this beam is
